overview.short: Cardiobacterium hominis is a fastidious Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic rod in the HACEK group, classically linked to subacute infective endocarditis.
overview.clinical_context: Often isolated from blood cultures in endocarditis; growth may be slow and require enriched media (e.g., chocolate agar) and prolonged incubation.

species_markers.notes: Indole positivity is a key supportive trait for Cardiobacterium hominis within HACEK.
Oxidase positivity supports Cardiobacterium over many oxidase-negative Gram-negative rods.
Helpful supporting feature when distinguishing from lookalike fastidious organisms with nitrate positivity.

common_confusions.reason: Closely related species; phenotypic differentiation may be limited without MALDI-TOF or molecular testing.
Shared HACEK grouping, slow growth, and similar clinical syndrome (endocarditis).

when_to_question_identification: Indole negative result (argues against classic C. hominis profile).
Robust growth on routine media without enrichment or prolonged incubation.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Confirms indole positivity and supports Cardiobacterium hominis.
Supports Cardiobacterium and narrows away from oxidase-negative Gram-negative rods.
Best practical method for distinguishing Cardiobacterium species in routine labs.
Recommended if MALDI-TOF is inconclusive or species-level certainty is required (e.g., endocarditis workup).
